notes: Seventh-generation Camry with sportier styling. Available with I4, V6, or hybrid. Hybrid uses CVT transmission. Best-selling passenger car in America for decades. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Camry article, January 2025 revision.

Eighth-generation Camry on TNGA platform. More aggressive styling. AWD available 2020+. Hybrid option continues. Improved handling and performance. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Camry article, January 2025 revision.

Eleventh-generation Corolla. Best-selling car nameplate globally. Available with manual transmission. Reliable and fuel-efficient. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla article, January 2025 revision.

Twelfth-generation Corolla on TNGA platform. Hybrid model added. Hatchback variant available. Manual transmission on select models. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Avalon full-size sedan. Available with V6 or hybrid. Flagship sedan below Lexus. Spacious and comfortable. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Avalon article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Prius on TNGA platform. Improved styling and handling. AWD-e optional. Prime plug-in hybrid variant available. Hybrid pioneer continues legacy. Hybrid systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Prius article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation RAV4. Best-selling non-pickup vehicle in America. Rugged styling shift from previous generation. Available FWD or AWD. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota RAV4 article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Highlander. Three-row seating for up to 8. Available with I4, V6, or hybrid. Popular family SUV. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Highlander article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation 4Runner. Body-on-frame construction. V6-only powertrain. Available with part-time or full-time 4WD. Off-road capability with crawl control. Long production run. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota 4Runner article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Tacoma. Best-selling mid-size truck in America. Available in Access Cab or Double Cab. Manual transmission available. TRD Pro off-road variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tacoma article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Tundra refresh. V8-only powertrains. Available in Double Cab or CrewMax. Maximum towing 10,200 lbs. Long production run without major redesign. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tundra article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Sienna. Only minivan with AWD option. Seven or eight-passenger seating. V6 powertrain. Replaced by hybrid-only model in 2021. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Sienna article, January 2025 revision.

Hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicle. 5.0 kg hydrogen capacity. 312-mile range. Zero emissions (water only). Limited availability in California. Fuel cell technology requires highly specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Mirai article, January 2025 revision.

Sports car co-developed with Subaru (BRZ/FR-S). Subaru-sourced boxer engine. Manual transmission available. Lightweight rear-drive handling. Affordable sports car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota 86 article, January 2025 revision.
